Consider the complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) satisfy the harmonic oscillator equations \\(\\ddot{x} = -\\omega^2 x\\) and \\(\\ddot{y} = -\\omega^2 y\\), with \\(\\omega\\) being a constant. We explore how the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\), which transforms a function into its frequency components, affects the inference capabilities within the system dynamics.

Given \\( z'(t) \\) at a time t = T, can we determine the original function \\( z(t) \\) at t = 0 by using the inverse Fourier transform without additional information?
Explanation: Since \\( z'(t) = z(t) \\), knowing \\( z'(t) \\) at any t is essentially knowing \\( z(t) \\) at that time. Therefore, applying the inverse Fourier transform at any point retrieves the original function exactly as it was at t = 0.
